I like the two sided bar, and even though one side is made for the youngest ones (under 3 months), I think it's great to be able to give baby a few different views and reverse it once in a while.  It only takes one D battery.  I'm not big on leaving these seats on too long anyway, I prefer to wait until the baby gets fussy, so I imagine the battery will continue to last a long time.  It has music, sounds, items to reach for and lights, in addition to vibration, so there's plenty to entertain a baby when needed, which set it apart from some other models.

I really love this bouncer! Though there's lots of blues, it's gender neutral and made by Fisher Price so it's high quality and very well made. This is the only bouncer I have seen that has a 2 sided toy bar, which I really love because it can grow with your baby. One side is all red, black, and white high contrast colors to help baby's visuals develop from 0-3 months. It has a light show and musical tunes too and the other side is for 3 months and up with bold colors and upbeat songs. It also has jungle animals and toys baby can grab and feel that have different textures/noise. The diversity of this bouncer is a big plus compared to others I've used over the years!I also like that it has a vibration unit built in to help calm the baby down when its fussy or colicky or just to lull him/her to sleep. I find the upright positioning great for babies that have acid reflux and can't lay down after eating right away. The seat cover is relatively easy to take on/off for when you need to wash it. It also provides a safe way to carry/entertain baby from room to room with you as you do household chores.It is a little expensive but the diversity and longevity you get out of this is well worth it. Another high quality Fisher Price product you won't be disappointed with!

This is a really good bouncer. It works well and baby likes itSome observations:Manual is not very good (every baby product we have used, had to look at the box to make sure things are right).Two independent battery operated devices: 1 (vibrator at the base) and 2 sound and lights on the toy bar on top.Might be able to self bounce.Fabric cleanable.No option for power from outlet, it has to be battery operated.On the unit I got, the middle toy stays turned 90 degrees from where it should be (strap probably got folded funny in packing)

This is a fantastic, very cute bouncer.  Our grandson, who is 8 weeks old, loves this bouncer.  Specifically, the incline seat which he is comfortable in and the calming vibrations which you activate with just a flick of the switch (product takes 1 D battery).  The toy bar is very easy to take out and switch around.  We have not used the colorful side of it yet due to his age.  The chair cover is machine washable and fits in any standard or even small washing machine.Thankfully, Fisher Price did not make a product where the noises go continuously.  That can grow quite annoying when it’s on a small 5 second loop.  To make sounds (assuming the music is turned off) the baby must be active to produce the music and motion.  I would remove only .5 starts if I could due to the price of the product at the time of the review ($55) which is slightly more expensive than other products which have similarly great reviews - something to consider for the price contentious buyer.
It can easily switch from use on the stroller to being carried.  makes for a nice small size organizer to use when grocery shopping.  I love how versatile it is.

Let me start by saying this bag absolutely looks like a fanny pack for your stroller. In case you are unsure, this is not a compliment. For what it is, I’m not sure what could be done to make it more attractive. Perhaps it’s the color and the lack of pattern that makes it so fanny pack-like. Aside from your stroller being dressed like a tourist, this works pretty well. I appreciate the fact that it hooks on both of my strollers – my umbrella stroller that has disconnected handles and my larger stroller that has connected handles. The “fanny pack” has two open areas for drinks/bottles. The stability is good enough for a baby bottle or any drink that has a cover. You may not want to put a fountain drink in the drink cups as this is a free-hanging device. The middle container is a good size to keep your keys and maybe a wallet or some small snack items. There are also two pockets in the front, a smaller open pocket and a larger zippered pocket.The two stroller hooks are standard and Velcro onto the stroller. They work well to hold a purse or diaper bag, or even a jacket. They are pretty standard when compared to other stroller hooks.I would recommend this kit if you have stroller that doesn’t have cup holders and if you do a lot of neighborhood strolling. It’s just right for a couple of (covered) drinks and you house keys/wallet/cell phone.Minus one star just because it’s kind of unattractive. I wish it had some pattern or texture to it.Sample received for review.

This is my first encounter with a Dot¨ stroller product and it's a really positive one.  No, you won't be able to put as much in it as a diaper bag or backpack, but it does keep all of those little essentials close at hand.  You can put everything in this organizer from a bottle to a diaper.What anyone wants to carry is a matter of preference or need, but this little organizer has options some I've tried don't.  For example, you can hang the organizer by the sewn-in clips / straps to the back of a seat in your car.  You can use the hooks to hang the organizer anywhere you want.  These attach to the organizer with 1" Velcro straps.  I like the weight option of 11 pounds, but doubt I'd ever put that much in the bag.The attention to detail is quite good and of course with the the 100% warranty, you know that Dot¨ stands behind their products. It's made of a sturdy combination of materials I often do see on backpacks. I do like the magnetic clasp on the larger center pocket.  It immediately snaps shut and would especially be a great storage space for a diaper.A bottle or can of soda fits well in the organizer, but at first I was worried about a taller metal water bottle.  One other organizer I had was a bit iffy in that department.  No problem because the holders are a full 6" deep.  They are about 3-1/2" wide and the fit was perfect, even for the wide Munchkin bottles I have.The reinforcement is really good.  There's what I'm assuming is some sort of plastic reinforcement on the bottom and thick wire (like a hanger) around the top.  The organized keeps its shape when in use, but can fold flat if you want to store it.  It's a high quality, one-size-fits-every-stroller and the back of any car seat.Sample provided for review.
Reviews.summary: Very high quality stroller organizer that will even hold the oversized Munchkin bottles ...

Reviews.reviewText: I have a huge stroller that has its own cupholders and storage, and then I have my little folding umbrella stroller which we use everywhere, on the go - at Costco, at fairs, at the mall, and at the grocery store. Unfortunately, that one doesn't have any storage at all, so if I want to put a sippy cup or my cell wallet in there, I'm SOL.This organizer bag is perfect because it straps onto the little stroller with no issues, the cupholders and pouches are great, and the straps adjust to fit on a car seat instead, so I can go from having a book and sippy cup on the back of the front car seat to having that bag on the stroller in a moment.The set also comes with free stroller hooks, which I have been using with my big stroller so I don't weight down my umbrella stroller too much.This product is well made and obvious how to use. Really glad to have it as it solves a lot of problems for me.
Reviews.summary: Handy bag converts from car seat storage to stroller accessory

Reviews.reviewText: I really like the idea of this product. I love something you can take from one stroller to the next with you that holds drinks, snacks, personal belongings and it is easy to take off/on as well as use.I first used this item while taking a walk in the park with my daughter. It was perfect for this ocasion. I was able to use the carrier to hold my cell phone and car keys for quick access. My daughter's snack case also fit easy in this spot but I could not fit her sippy cup (she has handles on the sides, so bigger width) or a water bottle for me because it was too heavy. Instead I used it more for pockets and storage which I could always use!After using this for almost a week I found myself using the hooks that come with this more than anything else. I have used the hooks so many times for many different reasons. I would buy this just for the hooks.I think the idea of this product is wonderful, it doesn't work for everything I would have liked it to but this gave me great extra storage while using my stroller and I really needed it to hold extra things, like a cell phone and camera without having to dig into my diaper bag.  The hooks are AMAZING!This product was provided by Dot & Dot in return for an honest review.
Reviews.summary: Great idea, love the extra storage it gave me while using my stroller. LOVE the hooks!

Reviews.reviewText: I have another stroller organizer that velcros onto the handlebar, I far prefer the clips on this one. I like the phone and zipper pouch. The cup holders are too small for my needs. I have a large tervis cup that didn't fit, which didn't surprise me but I tried to put a regular sized plastic bottle and it didn't really fit. My britax b-agile double stroller doesn't have a cup holder and I take my water everywhere so for me the small cup holder is a bit of a deal breaker.Overall the organizer is well constructed and looks like it will hold up nicely. The hooks are very well designed. I like that they rotate and swivel to accommodate any stroller or bag.Disclosure: I was given this product for free in exchange for an honest review.

I love this organizer! I received this to review and I really took my time with it to give it a good review. It is very sturdy, not flimsy. It holds multiple items, extra storage for baby's bottles or your cup, phone wallet and has attachable clips if you want to hook a diaper bag or any other hanging item to the stroller. Obviously it shouldn't be heavier than what the stroller can handle, but the option is there if you need more than the space already the stroller.Also,  if you need to carry the organizer from stroller, to car, or for me, airplane, it turns easily into a sort of purse and you're on your way.I will be recommending this for anyone I know that has a baby and needs a little more organization in their lives.

This organizer bag is made for use with strollers but it works quite well as a shoulder bag or in an automobile.  It is very durable, with nice zippers and reinforced seams and a magnetic catch for the main compartment.  The bottle compartments are even insulated.This is not sized as a diaper bag, but a couple of emergency diapers and some wipes can certainly be tucked into the center compartment.  The dimensions are approximately 4 in. x 13 in. x 6 in. tall.The hooks are easily attached and removed but fasten securely and swivel.  They will hold several grocery bags or a tote or youngster's backpack and are useful on grocery carts, bicycles, rollators, and lawnmowers—almost anywhere a hook is needed and there is something to fasten them to.Overall, this is a very well-designed and versatile stroller bag and the hooks are also indispensable.  It would make a lovely gift for a baby shower.Dot¨ provided a sample for evaluation and review.

Dot & Dot has created a medium-sized bag that can be used as a stroller accessory or hung from the back of a seat of a car.  I'm using it in my car.The bag is very lightweight, and it collapses to a small parcel easily replaced in the clear plastic zipper bag that comes with it.  The bag offers two drink holders, lightly insulated, a zipper pocket large enough to contain a wallet, some tissues, or even a folded diaper.  There's an open pocket for your cell phone, making it easy to retrieve, and a deep pocket with a magnetic seal for bulky items such as keys and medications.Here's my favorite thing in this accessory kit - hooks you can attach to stroller handlebars by adjustable velcro loops.  This is a hands-free way to carry a purse while you stroll around the neighborhood. I would not use it for that purpose in a mall because it would be easy for a thief to quickly unhook the bag, but where you are comfortable in your surroundings and want to have your purse with you, these hooks will do the trick.  I have not seen hooks like these and believe they'll be quite useful to mothers who need to keep their hands free to tend to baby.The bag is well-contructed of a rip-stop nylon type fabric.  Seams are tights with no selvage showing, zippers easy to operate.  Overall, this is a multi-functional bag for stroller or car.  I am pleased to recommend it.
Reviews.summary: Easy to Manage, Easy to Store

Reviews.reviewText: The particular stroller that I use (Chicco brand) has more cupholders than most strollers out there, but this stroller organizer gives me even more room for snacks and beverages while out and about.I use this organizer on walks and outings with my children (one of whom rides in the stroller, the other who usually does not).  This organizer gives me more room for our many beverages and snacks.  I use the middle compartment (which has a pretty secure magnetic closure) for snacks and the zippered compartment for my keys and phone headphones.  The sleeve to hold my phone is pretty handy, especially since upgrading my phone to a model that no longer fits in the little compartment on my stroller where I used to store it.  The cupholders are a pretty good size and hold larger cups and bottles as well.I attached the hooks to my stroller handle.  They are handy when out shopping, but I wish they had a more secure carabiner-like closure to them.  This is my only suggestion on how this product might be even better than it already is.I don't normally use the shoulder strap much but as we often visit theme parks where strollers must be frequently parked, I plan on bringing the longer strap along so that I can easily tote this around in rides/shows without having to leave it on the stroller when parked.  My plan is to keep my phone, keys, snacks, etc in it and just bring it around the parks with me.This product arrived nicely packaged in a reusable clear pouch, which was a nice touch.Overall, I would recommend this product to those looking for a sturdy, well made, thoughtful stroller organizer.  It definitely helps keeps essentials within reach when walking around.Sample provided for review.

My last stroller organizer bit the dust in less than 24 hours, it was very poorly made so I had high hopes for the Dot¨ stroller organizer. It really fits the bill, and then some! It is the perfect size for my needs, not too bulky. I usually only require a stroller organizer for short walks, so that is what I am basing my review on. The included accessory clips are perfect for connecting a purse or diaper bag for longer excursions, they are very sturdy.Specs:Size: 12.5” long, 6” tall and 4” deepI was able to fit my keys, phone, bib, Camelback .6L water bottle, Thermos Foogo bottle, binky, small toy and small snack container into the organizer - and there was room for many more small accessories. Keep in mind, this is great for small excursions or aerobic walk/run. For longer excursions when you might bring lots of items - the included stroller clips allow for you to attach a larger bag of baby stuff.This organizer fit on my Britax B-Agile and BOB Revolution strollers.What I love:-The packaging was fun - it came in a handy plastic pouch with a zip-top-Well made. The straps are sewn really well into the nylon lining, I don’t see them coming loose anytime soon.-The magnetic center pouch. Perfectly planned for mommy’s on the move, this compartment is perfectly placed and the magnetic cover makes it so easy to access for a binky, toy or snack when exercising. Nothing more annoying than grappling to zip or velcro open a pocket while trying to keep my pace, this one is SUPER simple.-It is sleek! I have black strollers and I really like that it just blends in - like it belongs on the stroller.-It keeps its shape and does not sag. I had another similar organizer that sagged and it drove me nuts, it is so difficult to reach for small items when everything is squished together. This organizer has an interior metal frame around the top and a thick lining on the bottom that provides a “platform” for contents to stand on.Overall, I highly recommend this organizer and would consider buying it as a gift for other mommy's as well!

This is a solid video/audio monitor.  We tested it at a house situated on a hill and the range reached from the top of the hill to the bottom (about five flights, through two walls).  It cut out some, but that was reasonable.  The battery life is obviously better if you turn off the video, and I though the battery life was fine.  Monitors I'm familiar with really aren't meant to be used long term without being plugged in anyway.I agree that the angle is a little tight and the picture quality is a little poor.  It also doesn't pan or tilt.  All of these features are usually on more expensive models though, so I think for the price this is a solid model.

This monitor is okay for the price, but it's not great. The video quality is acceptable, but often I can see the baby making noise and the sound doesn't come through the monitor. If I were going to use it long term, I would pair it with a basic audio monitor.

I really liked this monitor at first, but the second night of use I decided to unplug and bring the receiver over to my nightstand.  The night before I left it plugged in across the room on my dresser.  With our old Angelcare, the battery always lasted through the night (8 hours or less) but the VTech monitor was off when I woke up.  WTH?  Turned it back on and saw the low battery.  Nice.  Good thing my child is a sound-sleeping toddler who rarely wakes, and not an infant in need of several feedings in the night.  I will go back to my Angelcare.We tried it the next day during nap time, and the battery started to die (after a full charge) in under 3 hours.Original Review:We were using an Angelcare basic sound monitor, nothing special, before getting this.  The Angelcare's audio is still working after 2 years, but the display is no longer functioning.  We switched to this a few nights ago and I like it better.*The sound quality is good.  We use a noise machine in our son's room and the Angelcare always sounded very echo-ey.  With this VTech, the noise machine sounds like it's sitting on our dresser.  I can clearly hear my son if he makes any noise in the room.*The video display is good for this price point, but still mediocre.  The angle is not wide enough and takes some careful positioning.  I have nothing to compare it to, but I would imagine if you spent more on it you'd get better video. You can definitely tell what you're looking at, but it reminds me a bit of looking at an ultrasound picture when the room is dark.  You can make out his head and see him moving.  I don't know what I expected.  In any case, this is not a feature I require, so any video is nice to have.  I'm not sure how useful this would be with an infant.  My son is 2.  It is nice to see if he's in there standing up if he makes a sound, or if maybe he's just dreaming.*Very easy to hook up.  I made no adjustments to it and just turned it on.  It was dead out of the box and needed a charge, but we have not lost reception anywhere in our 1900 sq, foot house.  Our Angelcare had a cradle charger, and I do miss that, but the simple A/C plug works fine, too.*Talk back feature is nice.  Haven't used it yet, but I like having the option.  Especially for when my son jumps to his big boy bed.  Again, not sure if this would be useful for an infant.I have this sitting on a dresser, so I have not tried a wall or ceiling mount, but I would imagine you'd get better visuals if you did that.  As it is, I can see my son through the crib bars, but it's not the best line of sight.Overall, I think this is a great and inexpensive video monitor, and I think it's more than adequate for most people's needs.
Reviews.summary: Battery died sometime in the night after a full charge

Reviews.reviewText: I've gone through a couple of video baby monitors so I have compared this one to the others that I have used.Pros:  Easy to turn the parent unit's display on and off (very useful when you are sleeping in a dark room and want the noise alerting function of the monitor to wake you up when necessary, but don't want a lit up screen on all the time).I don't plan on using the talkback feature with this unit, but it does work fine.Cons:Picture quality is pretty poor. It also seems to have a pretty tight camera angle; I have to set the camera further away than you would think to get the whole crib in the picture.The infrared nightvision is pretty weak compared to other monitors I have used.Camera mounting options are limited. You can either set it on something and tilt the camera up and down or screw it into the wall. Maybe it is just my nursery setup, but I've got a high shelf above the crib that I like to put the monitor camera on. Other monitors that I have had came with a clamp that I could use to mount the camera on the edge of the shelf to look down on the crib. This one does not. I'd rather not drill holes in my wall for a baby monitor and it doesn't tilt far enough down to set up on that shelf.The settings menu on the parent unit has no words, just pictures, so good luck figuring out what those mean.Overall, this monitor looks and feels a little cheap. I can't think of a reason I would recommend this monitor, since there are others such as the Uniden UBR223 at about the same price or just $10 more that I think would be better buys.

We had high hopes for this VTech monitor, one that offers both video and audio monitoring of your babies or toddlers. Set up out of the box was easy; it was fun playing with the unit set up in the garage for experimental purposes while watching our grandson play with his trains. The picture quality and sound are good, and the talk back feature is especially useful as well as fun. We did soon discover that if low lighting the visuals are mostly monotone.Random thoughts:Setup was a bit tedious. Unit should be at least three feet from the crib or bed. It was hard getting the right angle. There's no side to side rotation, just forward and back and up and down.If you can find the sweet spot, the unit is great.Battery life is not good. When not using the unit, it's best to turn off the video function to lengthen battery life.There is no belt clip for the parent unit.Bottom line - The VTech unit has its good points, but doesn't hit it out of the park.

If I had written this review the first day we hooked the LorexBaby Little Link up, I would have given it 5 stars.Really easy to set up and simple to use.  Awesome clear picture, love the voice ability, LOVE the lullabys, super love that I can watch the baby on my phone.But the next morning, no picture. We reinstalled, started over again, PERFECT! For a couple of hours, then Poof! no picture.We noticed that there a note to keep the monitor at 62 degrees (seriously? in a baby's room?) so thought maybe it had overheated as the room temp was 72 degrees. Removed the camera from the room to the coolest place we could find in our house for a few hours, then replaced it. Working again!Room temp now 67 degrees. Two hours later, no picture. Ok, maybe it's overheating because we are keeping it plugged it? Unplugged it, allowed it to die, then keep track of how long it is on. Still turns itself off.We've tried turning the music off, turning the night light off, wondering it those are somehow draining it? Nothing works.We are at a loss as to how to keep it running. The only thing that has worked at all is to remove the camera and cool it, and then get a few hours of use before it once again stops.The product is a wonderful idea, and when it works, it is truly fantastic. Sadly, for us, that is about 10 hours of use in almost a month of owning it.
Reviews.summary: It's an awesome monitor...when it works

Reviews.reviewText: The Lorex LBN511 Little Link Video Baby Monitor is a small but powerful tool to keep your eyes upon your infant from anywhere in the house or, for that matter, from anywhere in the world.The Little Link monitor uses wireless connectivity using the camera’s unique ID number to connect to secure and protected Lorex cloud servers so you can use your smartphone or tablet (iPhone or android platforms) from any room or any other location you might be in to connect to the camera and monitor your baby’s room.The camera’s HD resolution makes for a very clear view and also comes with Crystal Clear Night Vision. The device will send motion, sound and room temperature alerts to whatever device you are using.The monitoring camera also allows you to take photos which than can be saved to your device to be shared with friends and family. It comes with a two-way talk feature so you can speak and baby hears your voice through the monitor.With the rechargeable battery the monitor can be operated cordless at other locations for up to three hours. But leave it plugged in and you have 24/7 surveillance.And once baby grows up and doesn’t require the same kind of close attention you can use Little Link for general home monitoring, which might be quite useful while away from home for an extended time.The biggest improvement that could be made is to make Lorex Little Link compatible with Windows so it can be used on laptops or PCs.
Reviews.summary: Baby Monitor is Provides Clear View at Home or Elsewhere

Reviews.reviewText: Pros:Hotspot technology does not require router connection, 300' range (I've only tested this within the house, with no issues)Password securityCamera can be used without the base; 3 hours of operation on rechargeable batteryGreat night visionNight light, lullaby tunesTake pictures and video to your phone (1280x720 or 848x480 resolution)Two-way talkMotion event recording to optional SD cardMotion, sound, or temperature alerts, all of which work pretty wellCons:3-hour battery life is not much, although not sure when you would use this. You could pair it with a portable recharger, I suppose. Still, a nice option.Cannot view on PC or MacCouldn't seem to record video AND two-way talk at the same time

I like this baby monitor, the set up is very easy unlike some WIFI devices. Simply plug in the monitor, power it on and download the app (iphone / android only, sorry windows phone owners). It has instructions too should any issues arise.  It has HD streaming and SD streaming depending on bandwidth (HD is required for good non-delayed audio transmission). Tt works well, even in our 4,000 sq ft space with minimal signal loss. The image is crisp and clear, it has a light option and two-way audio which is pretty nifty. I wish that I would be able to use it with my desktop PC, but other than that its pretty cool with a nice elegant design.

As the title of this review says, this product just wasn't what I expected it to be. I was exciting when I ordered it through the Vine program. I have recently taken physical custody of my mischievous 3-year-old grandchild. I wanted to be able to keep an eye on her when I wasn't able to be in the same room with her and I found this product to be a bit difficult to use. I have a Samsung Galaxy Note 2 and to this day, I cannot get it to work on my phone. I've uninstalled and re-installed the required app and when I try to start it, it switches my wif-fi to 4G which can be pricey if it exceeds my data plan. I utilized the mini disc that came with it and it was just worthless. When you click on the many resources and apps it says are on the disc, it takes you to the company's website. One of the resources on the disc is supposed to be the user manual, which takes you to the Lorex website, and for the life of me, I cannot find a user manual anywhere on it.I wasn't going to give up, so I tried the app from the Google Play store on my husband's Motorola Razr and it works just fine. I then tried downloading it on my iPad and first had problems, but was finally able to find the app by going through the Play Store through Google Search, because when I tried to put in the name of the app directly through the Play Store, it says app not found. I eventually got it to work on my iPad, but after about an hour it told me it couldn't locate my camera or it couldn't connect to the internet. Very irritating.Enough about my irritation, I will say that while connected to my husband's phone, the video is excellent. There is a delay from time to time but overall it has a good photo. The camera has night vision and a night light which I think it pretty cool. It has an option to capture photos or recover videos as well as sound and talk. Good product, if you can get it to work with your device. And, I'm in no means blaming the product, however, it seems to have obvious compatibility issues. I would think for $200 list pricing, this product would connect like a charm. And for $200, I would expect to receive 2 devices instead of the one that you get. I know home security system devices that come with 5 cameras for the same price.If the compatibility issues could be resolve this would up my rating to a 5.
Reviews.summary: It Just Wasn't What I Was Expecting

Reviews.reviewText: This little gadget is really cool.  It's convenient in that it transforms your cell phone into a baby monitor.  In order to use, you must download the Lorex app for your phone.  The biggest problem that I found is that Lorex uses it's own wifi which then switches you off of your homes wifi and it's a pain to keep switching back and forth.  I wasn't able to find a way around but then again I'm not super up to date on technology.  The picture is clear and sound is good.  It offers a feature to talk into the room so you can soothe your baby without going in.  Overall it's good / just wish it was easy to hook up to my home wifi.

I like the idea of the wifi feature of this monitor, and I hope it's safe and secure. I didn't experience any problems installing this. My phone is new enough that it was compatible, but I would suggest that everyone check compatibility before investing in this monitor.The images are fairly clear on SD mode. HD was too slow, but isn't really necessary for us. The color is decent as long as the room is well lit. The night vision works well, better than I expected. I was able to capture still images, which was nice. I haven't tried to record videos, probably because all I see are two little dogs sleeping all day. I do seem to lose contact every now and then, but it works well most of the time.The unit is lightweight and small. The nightlight is a nice touch and puts out just the right amount of light. It's easy to use, and I like the way it looks. Overall, I think this is a good monitor with nice features.
Reviews.summary: Not perfect, but it works well for our purpose

Reviews.reviewText: This is a really nice camera. Setting it up was very easy, got the app and I was ready to check it out.I first tried the night time and was able to see when the baby turned around, it activated itself. I was able to talk to the baby and soothe him without having to go upstairs. I then played one of the lullabies and the baby fell asleep again.You will need to have WiFi installed in your house to better utilize this product. We have wired and WiFi so we had no problems but for those with no WiFi this product will use your data plan.I liked the product but with the current price there are other cheaper alternatives in the market.

I am on the fence with this thing. I was surprised the thermometer was not packed with plastic around it. It seemed very exposed and knowing you are putting it in your ears, I did not feel very hygienic. However, I cleaned it off and all seemed well.It states it comes with 2 double AA batteries, not the case with mine. There was an empty spot were the batteries were supposed to be but there were no batteries. I had to put in my own. I don’t know if that was a quality control issue or not but it states it comes with them, has a spot for them, but they were no included.The instructions are not that easy to understand. Meaning, you follow the steps but yet the thermometer does not respond the way the instructions read. I finally figured out how to get it to work, however, the temperatures are very inconsistent. I tried it on myself and had a higher reading then normal. I then tried another one I have and it read a temperature almost two degrees lower. I then tried it on my daughter; it read the same temperature had. When we tried the other, hers read higher than the one it displayed.Right now I can’t recommend this item. I am going to try it out more but right now it is a not impressing me at all. The plastic does feel a bit cheap in your hands but the shape of the device is rather nice. I will say it is very easy to hold.If my readings change on it I will update my review. But as of not, I am not that impressed.Sample item provided.

My granddaughter is autistic and finds having her temperature taken difficult. So, when I was offered a complimentary sample of this product to test for a review, I had the perfect subject in mind.She was a bit squirmy, and I was concerned about whether I would be able to get a "good temperature." Once I figured out how to use the thermometer, it worked perfectly for her.The first issue involved the batteries (Included!). Somehow I didn't get one of them in tight enough and I wasn't able to close the back cover. My husband made sure they were inserted correctly and tightly, and it snapped down.Second, the instructions are confusing. I think they are confusing because they try to tell you too much. So I'm putting them here.To change from C to F setting, push the button once, then hold it down a second time till it changes.To take temperature. Push the button and wait till the F (or C) is flashing. Place probe in ear and push button once. Wait till it beeps and take it out.In checking ears at home, repeated checks came up with the same consistent temperature. My husband and I both measured 98.6 in both ears. :-) My granddaughter, who had been in the pool swimming was actually a bit cooler.Since this can be used at night without disturbing a child (or an adult), I have added this to my first aid kit.It did come in a very nice box with information on the box in addition to the instructions, so I wouldn't hesitate to give this as a baby gift to a new parent.Again, I received a complimentary sample from Gogogu to test for my revew.
Reviews.summary: Measures accurately ... not just for babies

Reviews.reviewText: This doesn't seem to be as accurate as the rectal baby thermometer my step daughter uses. It was within about .01 degrees however, so that's pretty darn close while avoiding the discomfort of a cold glass pipe up the pooper and MUCH less distressful for the baby. As a first goto, this is great. If there is cause for more concern, one might wanna go for the Howard Stern.When my son was small I had one of these and paid significantly more for it. (Not the same brand) This one seems to be of similar quality but more accurate than I remember, so maybe it is just simply that the cost of tech has gone down while improving? There are still more expensive options...but why? We all know that when the baby is sick, we are going for the easy check first but when real concern arises, nothing beats the back door for confirmation.Sample supplied without obligation.

This Gogogu Large LCD Non-contact Infrared Ear Thermometer is accurate and easy to use. Being a father of three, I have been a fan of ear thermometer for years and have used quite a few different brands. This one is simple to use and is very affordable. Here are my observations:Pros -+ Quality; well made+ Ease of Use; simple one button controls+ Accurate; tested against a much more expensive thermometer and produced similar readingsCons -- Instructions; somewhat lacking but easy enough to figure outOverall, this is a good choice for new parents or even for adults.Highly Recommended!CFHNote: Sample provided to review

As any parent will tell you, getting a temperature reading from your young child can be a real pain in the derriere. Most young children are not willing to stand still for the duration needed to get an accurate reading from a standard thermometer. A contactless thermometer seems to be an ideal tool for such situations. This Gogogu thermometer is indeed a godsend, but it's not without its limitations.This thermometer is for the most part easy to use. It takes only a second for it to get a temperature readings, which is really great. The small digital screen displays the reading clearly, although it could be a bit brighter.One major issue that I have with this thermometer is that the readings are not very consistent. I've done several temperature readings in a row, and each one of them ave me a slightly different result. Sometimes results were close to each other, but sometimes they differed by more than a degree. The results also varied with the ear that I used, also sometimes by a whole degree. The good news is that the thermometer is very quick and easy to use, so if you don't mind averaging several repeated measurements, then you will still probably get a good overall reading.Another issue that I have with this thermometer is that the instructions are not all that clearly written. It was hard to understand sometimes if I had to hold and release a button during the setup, or keep holding it. Nonetheless, with a bit of trial and error I managed to get it working.The thermometer fits nicely in your hand. It is not built from the highest quality plastics, but it does get the job done. I would certainly continue using it and do recommend it to other parents - especially considering its affordable price.**** Product sample provided for review purposes. ****

This appears to be modeled after the more expensive Braun model and works as well for us so far.THE GOOD-No probe covers needed.-Easy to read backlit display.-Simple to change from Celsius to Fahrenheit by just holding the power button for a few seconds.-Accurate. Better than several other ear thermometers I've bought at drugstores.-Quick. Readings in just one second.-Beep is not too loud. One model beeped so loud it woke my daughter every time I tried taking her temperature while she slept, This one is fine.THE BAD-Feels a little cheap. Battery contacts had to be bent into place.-Although it's advertised as including batteries and there's a space for them in the box, batteries were missing.-A storage pouch would have been nice.I love the ease of ear thermometers and this is a good pick. Packaging on my box says Babyly Infrared Thermometer-- not sure if they changed brand names.Received for review.

To use:First remove the battery cover (by lifting up on it) then  install the included AA batteries. Be sure to install the batteries properly. If you have problems check Amazon's product images. A photo shows correct battery placement.Choose Fahrenheit or Celsius, press & hold the power button until your preference, F or C, appears on the screen. When your preference is displayed, release the power button.To take a reading...1. Turn on thermometer, the screen will display '188.8' & all the icons2. Screen will display the last measurement3. Then it will display 'ready' --- F or C (according to which you chose)4. Insert the probe just into the ear canal (not too far)5. Press & release the power button, when you hear the beep, remove the probe...the temperature will be displayed.6. If no measurements are taken the thermometer will shut off in 30 seconds7. After each use, clean the thermometer & probe with a disinfectant wipe or cotton ball soaked in alcohol. The thermometer is not waterproof. Do not immerse it in liquid.Wait 30 minutes  after exercise, bath or meals before  taking measurements.It is normal to have temperature deviations in measurements taken between short intervals. In this case, average the temperatures.The thermometer  appears to be accurate; however, I can't get the battery cover to snap in place. I think it has to do with the battery contacts. If I remove the battery on the right side, the cover snaps into place. I tried adjusting the offending contact, but I don't want to break it by adjusting it too much. I will probably use painter's tape or a rubber band to hold the cover on.The thermometer feels good in my hands & gives almost instant readings. The beep isn't very loud so it 'might' not disturb a resting baby.satisfaction guaranteedreview sample provided
Reviews.summary: Almost instant temperature reading...2 AA Batteries included

Reviews.reviewText: Well, everyone knows what this is for, nothing new. But I must say, I've used many and it is hard to find one that sits comfortably on your shoulders and doesn't feel as if it pulling you towards the ground chest first no matter how light the cargo. The padding on this carrier is excellent. I didn't feel any pressure on my shoulders or my back. Also, it feels extremely sturdy, as well.A great purchase.

I have a baby bjorn from many years ago and I didn't expect much comparison with this one, seeing as the price of one is almost 5x the other. But I was pleasantly surprised by the design and construction on this no-brand carrier. The material seems sturdy enough and the design is very similar to many others that are sold at much higher price points. It does have a slide-on type latch (hard to describe) that is hard to do one-handed (which is how you normally put the straps on). Other carriers normally use a safety-belt type buckle that's easier to snap on together. We'll see how well this holds up with regular use.
Reviews.summary: The material seems sturdy enough and the design is very similar to many ...

Reviews.reviewText: This baby carrier is SOOO much better than the one I used when my youngest was a baby. It is easier to put on - and adjust - the comfortable padded shoulder straps and waist strap.The carrier has many adjustment points, too, to adjust for the changing size of the baby, which makes for a more secure ridealong.It is sturdy but padded and comfortable for both baby and whoever might be carrying.The clicking latches with a green indicator are a neat idea so that you know baby is securely fastened in.There is a zippered flap on the front of the carrier that can be opened to allow air circulation through a mesh covering. On the other side of the flap is a mesh pouch with a Velcro fastener to store smaller objects in. It isn't big enough for a diaper but could be used for house key, phone, pacifier, cash, credit card.Baby can face either facing whoever is carrying him/her or can face outward facing the world.It also comes with a nifty carrying case that fits the carrier nicely.It is made for babies 8-26 pounds.This is one of the nicer, easier-to-use carriers I've seen and well worth the price.

Wow, compared to what I used for my own child, this is a breeze to put on and attach.  I sat down on the couch and put it on and then put my nephew into it and latched him in.  This says it can be used up to 26 pounds, but I found it tiring to carry a 25 pound baby in it for very long.  When I got this I read it wrong and thought it could be used in front or wear on my back, but it's the baby who faces different positions while you carry him like a kangaroo.The latches are ingenious, just sliding in, then you cinch it to the correct size.  Lots of padding on the shoulders and for the baby's head makes it pretty comfortable.  The support is just right, and there is a way to adjust for height for the baby so he's always in the right position.

The padding on the MLB carrier is awesome. I used to use a Bjorn which cost so much more, but this one is great. It's also adjustable everywhere, so if it doesn't feel quite right, just move a strap or two. Baby can face you or the rest of the world. I'd recommend this product.

This is the easiest of the bunch I have tried (3 or 4)If it's complicated, I don't want to use it.It still has a lot of adjustments to make sure baby is in the right position and secure.I like that it adjusts for little infants to older children (for example the leg hole adjustments).To be honest, I'm not a fan of the sports logo but the carrier is so good that I don't care.
Reviews.summary: The easiest (and best) one I've tried

Reviews.reviewText: Majority of baby products are out there are very much catered to women so it was great to find a great quality baby carrier that's a perfect fit for the dads out there!Don't let the sports logo branding fool you - this is a top notch carrier. The shoulder and waist strap are excellently padded for maximum comfort and support for the parent. The seat is also padded making it equally comfortable for the baby. It's easy to make various adjustments to the straps to ensure the perfect positioning, and also to adjust the carrier as your child grows (can be used for babies 8-26 lbs).
Reviews.summary: Top Notch Carrier - Perfect for Dads

Reviews.reviewText: We have owned many baby monitors over the years. We got this after the $130 model failed to impress. This less expensive one has fantastic reception. It receives reception through closed doors and one floor apart. There is no static, and it picks up sounds with beautiful clarity. Easy to use. Great for newborns through toddlers.Great addition to any nursery!

Apparently you get what you pay for.  I've used Philips audio monitors for our last three kids, but it can be a pain to move your in place solution when you just want to visit a friend or relatives... drop a cheap audio monitor in your bag and go.  Well..  that would really be great if the units would connect consistently.  The whole point of the technology is to use it through walls in normal buildings.  If you have to have line of sight to the device for the radio to be able to maintain connection reliably, well the unit is unnecessary then.I'll deal with taking my more expensive quality units with me - because getting a cheap one certainly doesn't give me confidence with the static and loss of connection experienced with these.
Reviews.summary: Spend more on a proven alternative.

Reviews.reviewText: This monitor is cheap and doesn't work well. Over half the night it stayed out of range, which is strange, since my house isn't THAT big and other monitors have worked. Not a fan of this on AT ALL.
Reviews.summary: Don't be cheap, buy a better one!

Reviews.reviewText: The old saying holds true with this product -- "you get what you pay for".  While, I like the, LED lights which signal noise in your baby's room, I am not comfortable using this digital monitor with a small infant during the night. Battery life isn't great for this product. It doesn't live up to the "static-free" claim either. And, while the volume control function seems to work okay, but the product overall makes me a bit nervous.Best use might be as more of an intercom with an older child.I'd recommend paying a bit more and getting one with higher review ratings - Overall a disappointing product.

These monitors do not work at all, I even attempted to contact customer support to figure out if there was a resolvable issue but they will not get back to me. These monitors connected to each other easily but the connection is lost frequently even at close range and when sitting still! They will be on for a few minutes, then lose connection and have no sound, then back to working again. I would NOT recommend these monitors at all.

Pros:Can be used for younger babies than any other jumper. 2 months! We didn't buy ours till four months, but we definitely could have used it at two! Of course, you have to know your own baby...a baby who prefers to sleep most of the time who hasn't yet developed much muscle tone should never be in a jumper or any kind of baby seat. But our kiddo came out of the womb with great neck support (really, the nurses were amazed), so you really just have to know what your own baby is capable of!Only jumper on the market truly designed to be ergonomic. Not that other jumpers are all bad, but if you really want one designed with baby's development in mind, it's an easy choice.Environmentally friendly. Seriously. This thing is made mostly of canvas, bungee and steel, with only a few very small plastic parts (good sturdy plastic, not cheapo flimsy plastic) and it comes packaged in a flat cardboard box barely bigger than an LP cover. A far cry from the big plastic things that come in huge boxes with lots of styrofoam packaging. And it can be reused for several children.Machine washable. Need I say more?Very durable. I was concerned that the snaps might come undone, but these snaps are heavy duty. They're not going anywhere! The fabric is also very thick and well sewn. The construction is really quite impressive.Easily transportable. Order a couple of extra hooks, or pick some up at the hardware store, and you can easily move it from room to room, or to Grandma's house, or wherever.  I haven't used the Kling Klamp, but we didn't have a need for it. If screwed securely into an overhead wooden beam, the hook isn't going anywhere! My hubby tested it by hanging from the hook himself before we hung the jumper from it. I recommend this, since you want to make sure that not only is the hook secure in the beam, but the beam itself is secure on the ceiling. Probably especially a good idea in older homes.Easily adjustable as baby grows.Excellent customer service. I contacted the manufacturer to order more hooks and discuss the possibility of getting a second fabric seat, and they were extremely helpful.And of course the best part: the babies LOVE it! At least our little guy sure did. Bouncing is fun! There are no bells and whistles, but I just attached little teething toys and crinkle toys to it with those plastic link thingees...kept him busy for quite awhile!Cons:Only one, that it's really not terribly easy to get baby in and out of. It takes some getting used to. But once you get the hang of it, it is so, so worth it! And honestly this fact actually makes me feel even more confident about baby's safety...if I have a bit of a hard time getting him in and out, he's definitely not going to work himself out of it!Overall, I highly recommend. Worth the money (and if you don't have that kind of money, I'm sure you could find one secondhand...really, it's that great!) I'm looking forward to using it for our second baby on the way!Update, 2013: We moved into a new home, and the beam we screwed this into for our second baby had a layer of plaster coating. Because of this, we did not notice that the hook was slowly twisting its way out of the beam, which had NOT happened in our apartment! The hook fell one day and our little son fell, and was upset, but was not hurt (wasn't a long fall to the floor, and we had a mat underneath). He loved this bouncer so much, though, we decided to figure out a better way...our doors were too narrow for the Kling Klamp to be practical, so instead we bought an extra hook. We screwed both hooks into the beam as securely as humanly possible, right next to each other, and hung the chain from BOTH hooks. The two hooks linked by the chain prevent one another from twisting, and if one somehow manages to let go anyway, the other is there as backup. We've had no more problems.
Reviews.summary: Great investment. Update: Two hooks are better than one!

Reviews.reviewText: My son is a little over 3 months old, but we already use this quite a bit. I started putting him in it when he was 2 months old (he is a big boy), and he seemed to enjoy just hanging there and "walking" around. At 3 months he started started to bounce; he gets a huge grin on his face. He will also kind of moonwalk around in a circle. He likes being able to turn around and see everything in the room.We didn't have a door frame with a good location, so we just put the hook into a stud in the ceiling in our living room. This gives little buddy plenty of room to jump around, and the whole family can sit and watch him. I like that you can just take it down and store it when not in use, unlike an exersaucer that would take up the entire floor. The hook, though very strong, is not that noticeable, and will only leave a small hole when it is removed later. My over 200 pound husband can hang from it, so I am confident that it will hold the baby with no problem.It does take a little while to ship to the US from Canada, so order ahead of time if you want to start using it as soon as the baby can hold its head up. Note: you can get free shipping on the Merry Muscles website. I also ordered a couple of extra hooks so that we can hang it in different locations (we have one at the grandparents' house, too).Update: At 9 months, this is his absolute favorite activity. He can jump really high, and he likes to spin around until it is all wound up, then pull his legs up and spin fast as it unwinds! This is easily a 30 minute distraction for him, and I feel it is making his legs strong to prepare for walking. So glad I bought this!
Reviews.summary: Great quality, fun. Worth the money.

Reviews.reviewText: Overall I'm happy with this jumper. It looks really cute in my living room and it doesn't take up very much space. My 4 month old baby loves jumping in it, and it seems safe and well made. However, I'm only giving it 3 stars because of these complaints:1. The price is really high.2. It is hard to get a baby in- You have to unsnap the side and then hold the baby up with one arm while you use the other hand to snap the side snaps around the baby.3. The chain that it comes with is too short. We had to use our own rope to hang it.4. Adjusting it so that the baby is the right distance from the floor and not leaning too far forward or backward or to one side is difficult and time consuming, and it will have to be readjusted as the baby grows.

a lot of people may be dissuaded from purchasing this jumper because of the hefty pricetag ... but it is worth every penny!!!!  my son absolutely LOVES his merry muscles and spends a lot of time in it.  we have it hung from the ceiling in our kitchen/living room so we can see him wherever we are.  this thing is the best!!

We started using this jumper with our little boy when he was about 3.5 mo old. At that time he wanted to be upright all the time and would jump and run in our arms, so we thought it was time to get this set up.  It wasn't a hit right off the bat, the first week took some getting used to on his part.  The first day he actually cried right away, but by the end of the week was content hanging.  Being so small, the front bib was level with his nose and for the first month he spent most of the time licking the white buckles and chewing on the bib (he's teething heavily).He's now just shy of 5 mos and starting to look like the bouncing baby on the merry muscles website... the coordination is setting in and his bounces are coming in a better rhythm one right after the other.  He will lock eyes on it (we keep it hanging) when he's wanting to get in.I love the simplicity of this product compared to the fisher-price style bouncers with all the bells and whistles that are stimulation overkill!  The set-up was pretty simple, we moved the strings only a few times to see what worked best for his stature and have it on the smallest buttons so far.  I was really hesitant about screwing the hook into the ceiling and creating a hole but the klamp is a bit pricey and in the end the hole in the ceiling is so small I won't even notice after we take it down.

I read a lot about this before I ordered it, and I was a little skeptical. When it finally arrived, from Canada, I was so excited ... then I opened the box. It looks like nothing! Looks cheap, and kinda ugly ... BUT, OMGoodness ... it is the best thing I have bought for the baby thus far. He loves it. He loves, loves, loves it! I love it! Everyone loves to watch him in it. It is so funny. It wears him out, strengthens his muscles, and gives him exercise he typically would not get as he is not able to walk. I believe he was in this at two months, maybe three ... read the description for the product to be sure, either way it is designed to be used earlier than other jumpers. I had him using it and then checked in with my Dr on the development of his legs and feet and he said everything looks great!My son is big, started out really small 6.14 ... but he grew fast, so I had to take out a set of stitches on the opposite side of the snaps. Read the directions on that because it is important. I figured out I needed to do that after calling the company to inquire as to why he would be jumping using only his left leg. I removed the inner set of stitches (there are two)  which made the bodice part wider, even on both sides, and he was back to two feet!Great, life saver, fantastic, wonderful, I love it!Make sure you safely secure the hook in a stud, make sure it is secure!!
Reviews.summary: Don't settle for any other jumper! LOVE THIS!

Reviews.reviewText: This is far and away the BEST baby jumper available.  After much research, I bought one for my twins when they were 5 months old.  At first, I was a bit disappointed.  It looked so homemade out of some fabric and stuff picked up at the local hardware store, and my boys just sort of hung there in it and didn't try to bounce much at all.  They only liked it if somebody sat there and bounced them or swung them very gently.  BUT NOW, at almost 8 months, both of them have a blast jumping in this.  My "older" bigger twin who is generally a bit ahead of my little guy LOVES the jumper and I think he would stay there all day if I let him.  They both enjoy it so much that I decided to buy a second jumper.  It is expensive, but very much worth it, and this provides much more entertainment and exercise than an exersaucer or jumperoo (plus it takes up much less space, which is at a premium in our house).  I highly recommend this jumper.A few tips:  1. Take the time to adjust the jumper properly the first time.  There are videos online that will guide you through the setup if you need some help.  2.  Put something soft on the floor for baby to jump on.  We were using a foam exercise mat, but now we have a memory foam bathmat there, and both my boys love it.  3.  Don't assume you have to stop using this when your child learns to walk.  The weight limit is 40 pounds.  We tried this out with my 18 month old, 25 pound niece and she had a blast in it too.**Update:  My twins are now almost 15 months old and about 30 pounds and they still enjoy jumping in their Merry Muscles bouncers!  There are very few toys that have lasted this long.  Thanks Merry Muscles!
Reviews.summary: So much fun, we had to buy a second one!

Reviews.reviewText: My baby just started to learn how to really jump/bounce in this and he is a bit past four months.  I started him in it when he was about three months and he enjoyed being bounced while I helped him and held his hands.  Last night he jumped in it NONSTOP for 25 minutes and I had to stop him from bouncing more.  You can easily see why babies have a hard time getting to sleep; they have a lot of pent up energy and no way to release it!This jumper brings him independence to stand and move without his parents and you can tell the joy he has while he is in it.  I am sure that it strengthens his leg and stomach muscles and teaches him to find his balance.  I was going to shop for a thing that can assist your baby to walk (moon walker) but I just realized that I can use this Merry Muscles for that same task by just attaching some strings and a harness type thing to hold up above him so that he can walk unassisted but completely supported.This bouncer is definitely worth spending the money.  You can attach it inside of a doorway or can attach it to any horizontal bar such as a clothesline.  When the baby gets tired you can raise their height and push them as if they were in a swing. Many many uses and baby will love it.  Plus you can use from 2months - 2 years.

When I first purchased this product my baby did not know what to make of it and would usually sit there and get scared of moving. Now, that he is 5 months along he enjoys the bouncing and laughs whenever he jumpsThe material is sturdy and as long as we make sure that baby has something soft to bounce on (we have hardwood floors) he just has a blast. One side note on this product, make sure the knots on the big ring are close together with two in front and two in back so that baby does not lean one way or the other. Other then that I am satisfied with this product.

Only received yesterday, after a very long delivery time from Kidalog. However, first impressions are that it is expensive for what it is, and has a very 'home made' feel to it, as though it was knocked up in someone's garage from items purchased at the hardware store. On the overall design front, it is pretty hard to get the baby in and out of due to the hoop above getting in the way, even when precisely following the company's instructions about sitting in a chair to do so. On the bouncing front, too early to tell, but so far our three month-old hasn't taken to it, but we expect she will!

We debated buying one vs. two, and ended getting two.  We are so glad we did.  They jump 3 times each day, and one especially would do this most of the day if we let them.  We tried our boys (longer than average in length, but slim) in these at four months, but they were a little too small and were scared of the unfamiliar feeling.  We kept trying, gently rocking them and supporting them as they got used to a light swinging and bouncing motion.  Within a week, one was having fun, and a couple weeks later, this was the favorite activity of the other.We have one concern though:  Our boys, now almost 7 months, are jumping vigorously but I recently noticed they jump with toes curled inward (on pointe, like a ballerina).  They aren't pushing off with the balls of their feet, so we're trying to get them to change this.  We worry about how this could affect their standing and walking.  Even when balancing on their feet while held by us, they tend to want to go onto their toes, not stand on their whole feet.  We wonder if others have the same issue, and how do we address it.

We did a great deal of research before purchasing this item, and loved the small size and seemingly unique features.  The main issue with this "swing" is that it is too SLOW!  Babies like small, fast movements, and even on the highest setting, this swing is very slow. It seems like a baby would like the gentle and smooth movements, but our baby didn't love it. Also the different "settings" all seem too similar.  It does not vibrate either, which, for the price, I thought would've been a nice feature. We didn't have another swing to compare it to, so we just used it anyway, but ended up mainly rocking her in the glider and doing the 5 S's as Harvey Karp suggests (he's a genius, by the way).  I would just get a traditional swing next time....if this item would lower the price by about $100 it may be worth getting and trying, but definitely not at the current selling price.  I like how it plugs in and is small, that's about it.  Keep looking...

I feel like I can give an honest review of this product because I researched it before buying it, watching videos, and "playing" with it in the store.  I had high hopes that were only let down after owning this bouncer for 2 weeks. Needless to say we returned this to get our money back.Overall, it's a decent "bouncer", which doesn't take up as MUCH space as a traditional baby swing. It was SUPER easy to assemble, no tools required, and just as easy to disassemble. It's very light weight too so it's easy to move about your home.  The idea you can hook up your ipod to it for music was great too. The "nature" sounds were okay and the volume levels were good! The plush material is really nice too.I was sure this bouncer would be the answer to my prayers. Having a baby (2 mo old) that LOVES to move, bounce, swing and be held. After seeing it work in the store, I thought the HIGH setting would be sufficient, however I was WRONG! the low setting is VERY VERY slow. The lowest 3 settings vibrated my baby, which would be okay if I WANTED a vibrating seat ALL the time. So I used the highest setting most of the time. Now, the highest setting, once my baby was in the seat, didn't move as "fast" or with the oomph like I had hoped it was going to. It's supposed to "mimic" mothers movement, but my baby, like I said, LOVES swift, quick, large movements. I see this same complaint in other reviews on this product. The overall noise level of the motor is "okay" it could stand to be quieter!So, my husband went ahead and purchased a Fisher-Price My Little Snug-a-bear swing. My baby will actually FALL ASLEEP in the swing; whereas, in the MamaRoo, he's start to fuss after about 15 minutes, nor did he enjoy the mobile. So after much deliberation and testing, the swing won out and the MommaRoo went back to the store. The swing cost HALF as much too. So we'll put the money we spent on this MommaRoo onto other baby products!So while this is a fancy swing, it's just that.. FANCY. At least for me and in my opinion. It wasn't as effective as I'd hoped it would be and I kept it for 2 weeks in the hopes that my baby would change my mind. It just left me with a feeling of... "I wish it did______" or "I wish it had this ______feature" (like a auto timer to shut off). Too bad they didn't make this bouncer with a locking/unlocking feature to use it as swing, like a miniature hammock. I understand they have a new product out that does swing and not bounce, but it would have been great to have both features in ONE item.So my advice: keep your receipt and the box JUST INCASE you purchase this with the same high hopes I had and then feel let down once you start using it and find it's just not meeting your needs.
Reviews.summary: Disappointed, I kept wishing for more.

Reviews.reviewText: I bought this for my new grandson (well, really for his mom) and she loves it and so does the baby.  I call it a "spaceship" because it's not really a bouncer and not really a swing.  This calms my grandson down every time we put him in it.The only thing I would change about the design is that the seat is too deep, causing the baby to slide down further, and his chin ends up right on his chest because his head is pushed forward, making it hard for him to breathe.  We put something at the very bottom to raise him up a bit.  He's 10 pounds and 6 weeks old, so he doesn't have much head control yet.With putting something under him, it's still easy to strap him in so he doesn't slide out.We absolutely love it and think it was worth the price.  It's relatively quiet and the music and sounds are soothing also.
I personally haven't used it, but any person I know that use one, they just love it!I can't wait to use mine!

Bought this on a whim after seeing it in action at a friend's house with their daughter. Our squirmy sometimes fussy daughter likes to be held, but is hard to put down. The minute I drop her in the MamaRoo and strap her in, SNUGLY, she stays as calm as when being held. The infant insert is a must, we didn't know there was an insert for infants at first and she kept sliding around, but now she is held snugly in place while she rocks around. She also seems to enjoy a variety of movements, and right when she is on the verge of waking up, I can change the pace and the style of movement and it usually buys another 15-20 minutes for the parental units.

We haven't had this very long, so I intend on coming back to update this review in the future, but wanted to share how much we initially love this. Our 6 week old wouldn't tolerate the swing one bit, has reflux, and is generally super fussy. We put her in this thing AWAKE and she sat there, smiling, while I got stuff done around the house. She would have NEVER done that with the swing. The mamaroo is so soothing, it puts her to sleep. I wear her a lot and love it, but sometimes I need a break or time to help my 2 year old and this thing is awesome.  So far, it's worth every penny.We were skeptical about buying this because our daughter likes to be rocked pretty vigorously, and so many reviews said it's too slow. While it isn't super fast or super rocky, I think the motion is just perfect. Obviously we've had moments where she's upset and this isn't a magic fix - sometimes, babies just want to be held. But I would absolutely recommend the mamaroo.UPDATE: Our now 4 month old still loves this! It got us through a couple months of colic and she's happily sitting in it right now, awake, just chewing on her toy. We recommend this thing to all our friends and are still super pleased we spent the money!

Despite the fact that the AAP and NHTSA (plus other lettered child safety advocates) have been recommending for YEARS that children stay rear facing AT LEAST until they turn two, this brand new forward only seat has instructions saying it can be used for 20lb 1-year-olds.  Of course, most state laws are behind on this, but I’d feel better if I thought a car seat manufacturer was more concerned with what is safe than what is legal.  Climbing off soap box now.As a mother of four kids between the ages of 5 and 11, I’ve installed and used quite a few car seats and I’m reasonably happy with this one’s ease of use.  The only installation issue was that the crotch strap was difficult to adjust.  We needed to move it to the forward position and this is typically an easy step.  The fabric had weird overlaps where you had to feed each section through separately (sorry that’s difficult to describe) and then the plastic slot was still tight.  I was tempted to fetch a hammer but managed to get it out.  The harness straps slide up and down with the head rest to make rethreading them unnecessary.  This is a plus.  I’ve always hated seats that needed to be removed from the vehicle to move the shoulder straps up.  The highest headrest position can only be used with the booster and this isn’t labeled at all so you might need to pull it all the way up and then make sure you slide it down a notch.Getting it into the car (or van) is pretty simple with LATCH.  It works like most other LATCH friendly seats.  The front of the base comes right to the front of our seat so it’s a bit thick.  The harness adjustment for buckling the child is easy and familiar.  I’ve seen this system with a pull strap on front before.  Pull the strap to tighten and release the tiny lever to loosen.  There’s a small pad attached to the crotch strap and the Velcro that holds it on is so small it doesn’t hold.  It came off the first few times I tried to buckle my child and I gave up on putting it back on.  It’s a comfort thing and not a safety thing anyway.This seat is bulkier and heavier than most booster only seats.  We’ll likely keep using it rather than buy a new one but I thought I should mention that.  It’s something to think about if you’ll be moving a booster back and forth between vehicles.
Reviews.summary: but I’d feel better if I thought a car seat manufacturer was more ...

Reviews.reviewText: With 3 little ones, we've ended up with several car seats to stock up the vehicles they ride in. Most of those are Graco, and they are the ones our children ride in the most. We are fond of them! The other two Graco seats are Nautilus, and this Argos is VERY similar.Installation was super easy! I pulled it out of the box flat. Just pull the packing pieces out, and the back flips up, and locks in place to the bottom. My husband installed it in our vehicle and had no issues, whatsoever.My youngest has been riding in this seat for the past month, and he loves it. He thinks he's big stuff now that he's facing the front! ;) The only issue is the fact that his(and my middle son's in his Nautilus) head falls down to his chin when he falls asleep. I'm sure that would happen with other seats, too, though. Otherwise, they are very comfortable in their seats!This is a 3-in-1 seat, but it IS only front facing. All three of the Graco seats we've used have only been tested out in the the 1st position.Again, we're very fond of Graco, and we've been pleased with this seat.
Reviews.summary: Similar to the Nautilus seats we have.

Reviews.reviewText: I recently installed the new Graco Argos 65 car seat in my F150 pick up truck.  This was replacing an existing seat that my son has used for the last 2 years.  Out of the package I found the instructions tie wrapped to the seat with step by step instructions on orientation and installation.  Once I locked the seat in the upright position (as directed by the instructions) I was able to install the seat in literally 5 minutes.  The installation was easy and I was impressed on how quickly it went in.  The most time I spent in this process was cleaning up all of the snack food my son had managed get under the old seat!  I would recommend this seat to anyone transitioning to the booster style.Also, it gave the passenger seat ahead of him more room to recline back since this seat is more upright which is a big plus because carseat usually take a lot of leg room away from other passengers, but this one doesn't. Give lots of space for everyone.
Reviews.summary: Fits in well, and works well.

Reviews.reviewText: My daughter is so excited to finally be facing forward. For her first week in the car, she sang about her new car seat. I got new car seat! I got new car seat!For anyone who does not read the description carefully, this car seat is forward facing only. Don’t be confused by the fact that it is a 3-in-1 car seat. All three iterations are forward facing and for children 20 to 120 lbs and two year and older.The seat was very easy and very straight forward to install. Strapping my daughter into this forward facing car seat is so much easier than her pervious rear facing seat, which was also a Graco. I wasn’t really sure at first why someone would purchase this type of seat (only front facing) instead of a reversible seat, but the answer to that became apparent after only a short while of use. A forward facing car seat is much easier to get my daughter in and out of even when compared to a reversible car seat facing forward. I’ve only used this car seat in the first mode, so I really can’t say how the second two modes work. I appreciate that the shoulder strap adjustments are done with a button that lifts the entire back so you don’t have to manually unthread and rethread the straps whenever you need to adjust the height.Overall, we are very pleased with this seat. My daughter seems to like it and I feel that it is safe and a good long-term investment since it will last until she no longer needs to be in a car seat or booster seat.

Short story, I was very disappointed with the quality and thought of the engineering on the product.  The best installation I could accomplish severely compromised the strap strength, but in a way that you may not notice or appreciate.  Save your time, check a different brand.Long story: I thoroughly researched the next carseats for our twin boys who are big-ish (90th percentiles) and just passing the rear-facing weight limits.  I compared this in-person to the prior model (Argos 70) based on Consumer Reports ratings.  This looked to be essentially the same.  Otherwise I may have gone for the Nautilus (for fear that the ratings wouldn't apply to this new model), but the Argos had slightly better crash ratings.  Let me say, it really is a nice looking seat, and the surfaces that come into contact with the toddlers are nice. I also really love the easily adjustable height. But...  I spent about 2 hours wrestling this thing around to try to get it to hold position in our seats.  I'm 6"4 and about 230lbs, so it should be pretty easy for me.  I've also had several seats now, so I'm familiar with different systems and mechanisms of installation.  And, I tried a number of different seat angles, clip placements, head restraint positions, etc.  Point being, I'm capable and was thorough.  For me, the fatal flaw was in the shell structure around the belt path.  I was using the LATCH belt, but the real problem was also present with a seatbelt install.  Namely, the path that the belt must take has it draping down over a plastic corner (so it bunches), some of which is 90degrees and rather sharp (e.g. it would cut a banana, or I assume a compromised belt strap in a crash).  Download the product manual, and you can see, on the page that has the warning that "Belts must lay flat," that the picture of the installation is not logically possible.  It has been altered with the LATCH attachments in the car shown angled (they are not), and a belt shape that on close inspection would lay in a squared U-shape to stay flat and negotiate the turns required by the routing guides.  I thought that this might be new to the new model, but I confirmed the same basic shape with the older Argos and with the Nautilus.  I didn't get out a ruler and measure, but it looked the same.  You can see that they have engineered a smooth belt path that exits directly out the back of the seat (i.e. it would run the belt parallel to the ground).  But, by definition, the belt needs to go back and DOWN at an angle.  Doing so brings it out of that smooth path and over a 90-degree section of the plastic shell (I'll see if I can upload a picture).This being my first time with this size carseat, I got a Britax model for comparison (our last seats were Marathons).  I immediately noticed the difference in engineering. It isn't even close.  The new Graco engineering/construction were similar to the 7-year old Britaxes (although they installed instantly and correctly in minutes).  The engineering and construction has come a LONG way since then.  I wish someone had simply told me that Graco seats weren't to be bothered with.  Furthermore, the biggest perk of the Graco (the design/style) is now offensive because it means they'll do R&D; but evidently only in the window dressing department (which admittedly, Britax could use a dose of).  Other issues: cheap single-belt (i.e. single point-of-failure) LATCH belt, cheap LATCH clips, no energy-absorbing tether,cheap shoulder belt pads, chest clip that somehow simultaneously is IMPOSSIBLE to open and can be opened instantly by a toddler, and worthless crotch belt pad which I think IS actually important.  Finally, for easy (i.e. cheaper) shipping, the seat folds back and forth (the first step of assembly in the manual).  By comparison, the Britax are static and have solid steel beams running basically l-shaped down the side (and have to ship in a big, expensive box).CHECKING FOR YOURSELF: PLEASE go look at some of these in a store.  Look at the belt paths, the clip quality, etc.  Tug on the crotch pad, feel shoulder pads, etc.  Check out the websites: one is all about "safety is when you have a pad next to your head" and the other is all about engineering and crash tests.
